content.text: Define _gravitational potential_ at a point
Show that the difference in gravitational potential \(\Delta \phi\) between points A and B is given by the expression
where \(G\) is the gravitational constant

The rocket motor is switched off at point A. During the journey from A to B, the rocket has a constant mass of \(4.7 \times 10^{4} \text{kg}\) and its kinetic energy changes from \(1.70 \text{TJ}\) to \(0.88 \text{TJ}\)
For the planet, the product \(G M\) is \(4.0 \times 10^{14} \text{N} \text{m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 1}\). It may be assumed that resistive forces to the motion of the rocket are negligible
Use the expression in **(b)**(i) to determine the distance from A to B
distance = .........m
A rocket is launched from the surface of a planet and moves along a radial path, as shown in Fig. 1.1

The planet may be considered to be an isolated sphere of radius \(R\) with all of its mass \(M\) concentrated at its centre. Point A is a distance \(R\) from the surface of the planet. Point B is a distance \(4R\) from the surface
The first law of thermodynamics can be represented by the expression
State what is meant by the symbols in the expression
During the change from A to B, the energy supplied to the gas by heating is 442J
Use the first law of thermodynamics to show that the internal energy of the gas increases by 265J
During the change from B to C, the internal energy of the gas decreases by 313 J
By considering molecular energy, state and explain qualitatively the change, if any, in the temperature of the gas
For the change from C to A, use the data in **(b)(i)** and **(b)(ii)** to calculate the change in internal energy
change in internal energy = .........J
The temperature of the gas at point A is \(227^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). Calculate the number of molecules in the fixed mass of the gas
A fixed mass of an ideal gas undergoes a cycle ABCA of changes, as shown in Fig. 2.1
Explain how it can be deduced from the expression that the block moves with simple harmonic motion
For the beam, \(k = 4.0 \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{s}^{-2}\). Show that the angular frequency \(\omega\) of the oscillations is given by the expression
The initial amplitude of the oscillation of the block is \(3.0 \text{cm}\)
Use the expression in **(b)** to determine the maximum kinetic energy of the oscillations
maximum kinetic energy = .........J

Over a certain interval of time, the maximum kinetic energy of the oscillations in **(c)** is reduced by \(50\%\) . It may be assumed that there is negligible change in the angular frequency of the oscillations
Determine the amplitude of oscillation
amplitude = .........m
Permanent magnets are now positioned so that the metal block oscillates between the poles, as shown in Fig. 3.2
The block is made to oscillate with the same initial amplitude as in **(c)**. Use energy conservation to explain why the energy of the oscillations decreases more rapidly than in **(d)**
A uniform beam is clamped at one end. A metal block of mass \(m\) is fixed to the other end of the beam causing it to bend, as shown in Fig.3.1
The block is given a small vertical displacement and then released so that it oscillates with simple harmonic motion
The acceleration \(a\) of the block is given by the expression
where \(k\) is a constant for the beam and \(x\) is the vertical displacement of the block from its equilibrium position
Explain the main principles of the generation of ultrasound waves for medical use
State **three** advantages of an optic fibre compared to a metal wire for the transmission of a signal
Show that the signal power \(P\) entering the receiver from the optic fibre is \(2.1 \times 10^{-5} \text{W}\)
A minimum signal-to-noise ratio of \(24 \text{dB}\) is needed at the receiver in order for it to be able to distinguish the signal from the noise
Determine whether the receiver is able to distinguish the signal from the noise
An optic fibre of length \(57\mathrm{km}\) is connected between a transmitter and a receiver, as shown in Fig. 5.1

The attenuation per unit length of the optic fibre is \(0.50 \text{dB} \text{km}^{-1}\). The transmitter provides an input signal of power \(15 \times 10^{-3} \text{W}\) to the fibre. The noise power at the receiver is \(9.0 \times 10^{-7} \text{W}\)
State one similarity and one difference between the electric field lines and the gravitational field lines around an isolated positively charged metal sphere
similarity
difference
Calculate charge \(+Q\)
On Fig. 6.2, sketch the variation of the electric field strength \(E\) with distance \(d\) from A to B, along the line AB
A small positive charge is placed at A. The electric field causes this charge to move from rest along the line AB
Describe the acceleration of the charge as it moves from A to B
A positive point charge \(+Q\) is positioned at a fixed point X and an identical positive point charge is positioned at a fixed point Y, as shown in Fig. 6.1
The charges are separated in a vacuum by a distance of \(10.0 \text{cm}\)

Points A and B are on the line XY. Point A is a distance of \(2.5 \text{cm}\) from X and point B is a distance of \(2.5 \text{cm}\) from Y. The electric field strength at point A is \(4.1 \times 10^{-5} \text{V} \text{m}^{-1}\)
Describe, with a labelled diagram, the structure of a metal-wire strain gauge
The strain gauge is initially unstrained with resistance \(300.0 \Omega\)
Use data from Fig. 7.1 to calculate the increase in length \(\Delta L\) of the strain gauge that gives rise to a potential of \(+2.00 \text{V}\) at point A in Fig. 7.2
The strain gauge undergoes a further increase in length beyond the value in **(b)(i)**
State and explain which one of the light-emitting diodes, X or Y, will be emitting light
In a strain gauge, the increase in resistance \(\Delta R\) depends on the increase in length \(\Delta L\)
The variation of \(\Delta R\) with \(\Delta L\) is shown in Fig. 7.1
The strain gauge is connected into a circuit incorporating an ideal operational amplifier (op-amp), as shown in Fig. 7.2
State what is meant by a magnetic field
State the direction of the magnetic field
Explain why the speed of the particle is not affected by the magnetic field
Show that the diameter \(d\) of the semi-circular path is given by the expression
Use the expression in **(b)**<mark>(iii) to show that the time \(T_{\mathrm{F}}\) spent in the field by the particle is independent of its speed \(v\)
A particle of charge \(+q\) and mass \(m\) is travelling in a vacuum with speed \(v\). The particle enters, at a right angle, a uniform magnetic field of flux density \(B\), as shown in Fig. 8.1
The particle leaves the field after following a semi-circular path of diameter \(d\)
why the core is made of iron,
why an electromotive force (e.m.f.) is not induced at the output when a constant direct voltage is at the input
Explain
Use data from Fig. 9.2 to
calculate the number of turns of the secondary coil,
state one time when the magnetic flux linking the secondary coil is a maximum

An alternating voltage of peak value \(150\mathrm{V}\) is applied across the 1200 turns of the primary coil. The variation with time \(t\) of the e.m.f. \(E\) induced across the secondary coil is shown in Fig. 9.2
Calculate the resistance of the resistor
resistance = .........\(\Omega\)
On Fig. 9.3, sketch the variation with time \(t\) of the power \(P\) dissipated in the resistor for \(t = 0\) to \(t = 22.5 \text{ms}\)

A resistor is connected between the output terminals of the secondary coil. The mean power dissipated in the resistor is \(1.2 \text{W}\). It may be assumed that the varying voltage across the resistor is equal to the varying e.m.f. \(E\) shown in Fig. 9.2
An ideal transformer is shown in Fig. 9.1
State what is meant by a photon
All of the light absorbed by the hydrogen is re-emitted. Explain why dark lines are still observed in the absorption spectrum
Some of the energy levels of an electron in a hydrogen atom are illustrated in Fig. 10.1
The dark lines in the absorption spectrum are the result of electron transitions between energy levels
On Fig. 10.1, draw arrows to show the initial electron transitions between energy levels that could give rise to dark lines in the absorption spectrum
Calculate the shortest wavelength of the light in the beam
wavelength = .........m
Light in a beam has a continuous spectrum that lies within the visible region. The photons of light have energies ranging from \(1.60 \text{eV}\) to \(2.60 \text{eV}\)
The beam passes through some hydrogen gas. It then passes through a diffraction grating and an absorption spectrum is observed
Use band theory to explain why, unlike a copper wire, the resistance of an intrinsic semiconductor **decreases** with an increase of temperature
Define the binding energy of a nucleus
State the relationship between the binding energies of the nuclei that is consistent with this reaction being energetically possible
Calculate, for this reaction,
1. the change, in u, of the mass,
change of mass = .........u
2. the total energy, in J, released
energy = .........J
State and explain whether the energy of the gamma-ray photon is equal to the energy released in the reaction

A stationary nucleus of uranium-238 ( \(^{238}_{92}\mathrm {U})\) decays to form a nucleus of thorium-234 ( \(^{234}_{90}\mathrm {Th}).\) An \(\alpha \cdot\) particle and a gamma-ray photon are emitted. The equation representing the decay is
The masses of the nuclei are given in Fig. 12.1
